item.title: An IRC client in your motherboard
item.description: I made a graphical IRC client that runs in UEFI. It’s written in Rust and leverages the GUI toolkit and TrueType renderer that I wrote for axle’s userspace. I was able to develop it thanks to the vmnet network backend that I implemented for QEMU. You can connect to an IRC server, chat and read messages, all from the comfort of your motherboard’s pre-boot environment. “Why”? What kind of question is “why”?

item.description: The article compares the performance of Clear() and Fill() methods in Microsoft code analysis for Span operations. Surprisingly, Fill() outperforms Clear() by 1.06 times, despite expectations. Both…

item.title: How we’ve saved 98% in cloud costs by writing our own database
Mario meets Pareto
item.description: Discover how to find the best Mario Kart 8 build using the Pareto frontier method. This interactive guide explores multi-objective optimization of speed, acceleration, and other key stats to help you beat your friends on the race track.
item.author: (Antoine Mayerowitz)

item.title: The Design Philosophy of Great Tables
item.description: We’ve spent a lot of time thinking about tables. Tables—like plots—are crucial as a last step toward presenting information. There is surprising sophistication and nuance in designing effective tables. Over the past 5,000 years, they’ve evolved from simple grids to highly structured displays of data. Although we argue that the mid-1900s served as a high point, the popularization and wider accessibility of computing seemingly brought us back to the simple, ancient times.
item.author: (Rich Iannone and Michael Chow)
